Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Mutual Understanding Theory of Health Care Quality Frontiers

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award provides funding for the development of a science of health care quality that can provide an explanatory theory of the determinants of quality, provide a contextualized framework for health service research to understand what works, generate a mathematical model of critical inputs/output interactions, and generate metrics that provide institutional guidance rather than report cards. As with any science, the structure includes a theory that explains observable phenomena, Axioms, or First Principles that generate testable hypotheses and models, identification of relevant ontology, and methodologies, and above all, be useful. Beside the rather substantial impact of potentially transforming health care quality from an art to a science, the use of Unified Component Modeling to develop mathematical models of the principle components of our Mutual Understanding Theory of Health Care Quality, will impact data mining techniques, predictive modeling, characterization of stochastic and deterministic systems, Bayesian learning and data-user interface methodologies.

If successful, the results of this research will impact health care quality and cost, improve patient outcomes, and contribute to the broader field of service science. The increasing contribution of service industries to the American economy has opened interest in organizational structures that support service innovation, how to measure service productivity, the relationship between client satisfaction, including, marketing and objective outcome measures and appropriate methodologies for predicting service demand, service capacity, and inventorying employee skill-sets. This work will contribute to each of these areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This planning grant brought together experts in the areas of medicine, systems engineering, telecommunications and  cognitive science to explore potential explanatory models of the determinates of health care quality and has begun to generate mathematical models of health care delivery as a complex system. The approach examined what quality means at four different-but interacting levels: a) the interaction between patient and health provider, b) the interactions between the health provider and the health care system ,c) the interactions between the health care system and regulatory/payer agencies, d) the interactions between regulatory/payer agencies and society

Broader impact: Health Care struggles to balance access, quality and costs-with most of the emphasis currently on the cost side.  Developing a theoretically-driven quantitative model of health care as a complex system able to take into consideration local conditions, permits administrators and policy makers better understanding of what to expect for a given set of inputs. At the local level, this preliminary modeling has been used to improve access, provision of recommended services and satisfaction with care for a diverse set of ambulatory programs ranging from primary General Internal Medicine and Pediatrics through tertiary care in Pulmonary, Endocrinology, Nephrology, Gastroenterology and Cardiac programs.

A nucleus of researchers are expanding the research via peer-reviewed publications, policy change at a national level and at professional conferences

Modified by: John M Fontanesi
